title: China's love affair with high-speed rail
summary: Since 2008, the Communist Party has been frantically building stations for a high-speed train, or 'gaotie,' to connect remote areas, develop the economy and consolidate its power. Yet with slowing growth, concerns about the advisability of the gigantic and expensive projects have arisen.

title: US defense secretary cites evidence that North Korea sent troops to Russia
summary: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin's remarks are the first official US statement on North Korean troops being sent to Russia, which South Korean intelligence has alleged is in support of Russia's war in Ukraine.

title: Israel pounds Beirut in the area's 'most violent' attack since the start of the war
summary: After nearly a year of war with Hamas in Gaza, Israel shifted its focus to Lebanon last month, vowing to secure its northern border under fire from Hezbollah. Israel has since ramped up its strikes on Hezbollah strongholds and sent in ground forces in a war that has killed at least 1,580 people since September 23.

title: Harris calls Trump 'unhinged' for allegedly praising Hitler
summary: After Trump's camp referred to the VP's comments as 'outright lies and falsehoods that are easily disproven,' the former president boasted of his 'good relationship' and daily calls with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu while at a Georgia campaign rally.

title: In Sweden, the far right is waging open war on the Swedish Committee for Combating Antisemitism
summary: In a series of articles published in the newspaper 'Aftonbladet,' the Swedish Democrats, who support the right-wing government, have accused the independent body – which systematically points out its regular slip-ups – of being a political player.

title: French mass rape trial: 'The shame isn't ours to feel, it's theirs,' says Gisèle Pelicot
summary: Gisèle Pelicot took the stand on Wednesday to discuss the evidence presented so far in the Vaucluse criminal court, with her ex-husband and the main accused Dominique Pelicot watching from the dock.

title: Sluggish growth threatens global economy, warns IMF
summary: China's prolonged stagnation, the global rise in aging populations and the return of protectionism all point to mediocre prospects, posing a risk not only to prosperity, but also to social and environmental equilibrium.

title: Turkish Aerospace Industries HQ struck by explosion
summary: Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya described the blast at the top defense company as a 'terrorist attack' that has left at least five people dead and 22 injured, and said it was 'linked to the PKK,' a banned Kurdish group. Later Wednesday, Turkey's defense ministry said its forces struck 'a total of 32 targets' linked to the PKK in Iraq and Syria.

title: Inducing labor: A growing practice
summary: Despite the controversies surrounding the medicalization of childbirth, artificial induction is increasingly used as early as the 39th week in France and other industrialized countries.

title: A tiny, speedy dinosaur with wings
summary: A physics formula has helped explain the long strides of a Microraptor whose footprints, dating back over 100 million years, were found in South Korea in 2018.

title: Meta suspends accounts tracking private jet flights
summary: Accounts that had documented flights made by billionaires like Mark Zuckerberg, Donald Trump and Kim Kardashian are no longer accessible on Facebook, Instagram and Threads.

title: Greenland extends detention of whale defender Watson
summary: Paul Watson was detained in Nuuk in July 2024, on a 2012 Japanese arrest warrant, which accuses him of causing damage to a whaling ship in the Antarctic in 2010 and injuring a whaler.

title: Wendy Sherman: Russia's 'main purpose is to sow division in the United States'
summary: An advisor to Kamala Harris on international issues, the Democratic diplomat is convinced that Vladimir Putin is trying to influence the US presidential election.

title: Riots rock Lisbon after police shoot a Black man dead
summary: Following the fatal shooting of Odair Moniz, 43, on Sunday night, Portuguese police have reported a second night of rioting, with three arrests and some 60 incidents in and around Lisbon.

title: A purple emoji instead of the word 'rape': A paradox and symbol of speaking out on social media
summary: By fueling users' suspicions of possible censorship of content including the word 'rape,' platforms like TikTok or Instagram are reinforcing the political nature of speaking out on the subject, argues Le Monde journalist Pauline Croquet.

title: Ukrainian prosecutor general resigns amid corruption scandals
summary: Judges and other civil servants are said to have improperly obtained disability certificates, enabling them to earn extra income and, potentially, avoid conscription.

title: The US's ambivalent relationship to a welfare state
summary: Traumatized by the great financial crisis of 2008, the shock of Chinese competition and the Covid-19 pandemic, Americans are once again yearning for more state protection.

title: Roman Polanski settles lawsuit alleging director raped teenager in 1973
summary: The French-Polish film director, who fled the US more than four decades ago after being convicted of sexually assaulting a child, was set to face a civil trial in LA, but his lawyers announced on Tuesday that a settlement had been reached.

title: How the war in Ukraine is accelerating international use of the yuan
summary: Having stepped up its trade with Russia, which is under Western sanctions, China is promoting the use of national currencies in order to circumvent the dollar's dominance.

title: How Meloni rose from the post-fascist margins to a leading role in the EU in just two years
summary: The Italian president of the council, who comes from a 'minority world' as she likes to say, has stabilized her majority and made her mark on the European scene with her migration policy. She's now trying to rein in all checks and balances.

title: In Turkey, the newborn gang trafficking scandal has shaken the hospital world
summary: Twenty-two people have been arrested, charged with homicide as part of a network trafficking infants into private establishments.

title: Boeing workers reject contract, extend strike
summary: The extension of the strike adds to the troubles facing Boeing and its new CEO Kelly Ortberg, who earlier Wednesday expressed measured optimism the latest contract would be ratified.

title: Western officials confirm North Korean troops have been deployed in Russia
summary: NATO and Washington said they have proof of the dispatch of North Korean troops to Russia, announced a few days ago by Seoul and Kyiv. They have not confirmed whether these soldiers are expected to go fight in Ukraine.

title: France hosts conference on military and humanitarian aid to Lebanon
summary: Representatives from 70 countries and organizations are expected in Paris for what France hopes will raise the $426 million the UN says it urgently needs for Lebanon.

title: Rare original 'Little Prince' typescript to be auctioned
summary: The London rare books store Peter Harrington is putting the typescript and a passport of the author Antoine de Saint-Exupéry on sale in Abu Dhabi on Thursday.

title: Is there too much noise for our children?
summary: At school, in the cafeteria, on the street, and sometimes at home too, the noise levels to which children are exposed are high, leading to stress and fatigue.

title: Gisèle Pelicot, invincible even against 'lowest depths of the human soul'
summary: 'I'm not expressing anger or hatred. I'm expressing my determination to change this society,' the former wife of Dominique Pelicot, repeatedly sedated by her husband so he and dozens of men could rape her, told the court on Wednesday.

title: Trump likened to a 'fascist' by General John Kelly, his former chief of staff
summary: 'He certainly prefers the dictator approach to government,' said Kelly, confirming the White House candidate's fascination with Hitler. 'This is a window into who Donald Trump really is,' commented his Democratic rival, Kamala Harris.

title: US election: Newt Gingrich, the Republican dinosaur of the House of Representatives
summary: The former Georgia congressman was one of the main architects of the Grand Old Party's populist turn in the mid-1990s. Twenty years later, he was one of the first to believe in Donald Trump's move toward politics.

title: French interior minister wants football matches to stop when homophobic chants start
summary: Speaking on French radio on Thursday, Bruno Retailleau was responding to an outbreak of homophobic chants among Paris Saint-Germain fans during a home game against Strasbourg last week.

title: French luxury brand Hermès bucks trend with rising sales
summary: Unlike both LVMH and Kering (Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent), who posted losses, the group famous for its handbags and silk scarves saw sales rise by 10% in the third quarter.

title: Venezuelan opposition figures win EU's top rights Sakharov prize
summary: Maria Corina Machado and her ally, former presidential candidate Edmundo Gonzalez Urrutia, won the prestigious award for their fight for democracy under President Nicolas Maduro's iron-fisted rule.

title: Macron and the dangers of 'bluster' diplomacy
summary: Despite the many setbacks he has encountered, the French president claims to still play a key role in what he considers to be his 'reserved domain:' the international stage.

title: Paul Watson, speaking from his Greenland prison: 'I want France to be our home'
summary: The defender of the oceans is still in detention in Greenland pending a decision on his extradition to Japan, the Nuuk court ruled on Wednesday. In France, mobilization is growing in support of the activist.

title: Insect population collapse is grossly underestimated by high-profile work
summary: Two researchers identified methodological and statistical errors in the largest database on global changes in invertebrate populations, cited in more than 1,000 subsequent studies.

title: French government orders displaced Ukrainians to give up subsidized accommodation
summary: In the Grand-Est region, Ukrainians who have fled the war are receiving letters asking them to leave their homes, on the grounds that they have not integrated. This measure has provoked anger in Ukrainian groups.

title: Pro-Palestinian protests lose steam on American campuses
summary: As elsewhere in the country, students and faculty at the University of Missouri were disciplined following the spring protests. Despite criticizing the Biden administration's Middle East policy, Democratic activists may still decide to vote for Kamala Harris.

title: Lebanon's ancient city of Baalbek bears the scars of Israeli bombs
summary: Strikes have killed 50 people in the city known both for its Roman temples and as a Hezbollah stronghold.

title: Austria elects first far-right parliament president
summary: The far-right Freedom Party's candidate Walter Rosenkranz was elected with 100 out of 162 valid votes cast, current parliament president Wolfgang Sobotka said on Thursday.

title: Climate: Greenhouse gas emissions are too high, pushing planet toward +3.1°C warming
summary: Greenhouse gas emissions are still too high to limit the rise in global temperatures below the thresholds set by the Paris Agreement, warns the United Nations Environment Program, two weeks ahead of COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan.

title: On Telegram, Russian messengers of war
summary: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, the number of channels run by Russian 'war correspondents' has soared into the thousands on Telegram. These new propagandists assist in radicalizing the 'special military operation' initiated by Vladimir Putin.

title: Environmental activist fined for deflating SUV tires in Paris
summary: Maxime D. would insert lentils into the tire valves of these vehicles to call out the pollution they cause. He was fined €300.

title: Putin says ball is in Washington's court with US-Russia relations post-election
summary: The Kremlin leader was speaking at the end of the BRICS summit in the city of Kazan, where he had faced calls from some of Russia's most important allies for the fighting in Ukraine to end. Putin also held talks with United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres in the pair's first meeting since April 2022.

title: Israel and Hamas signal openness on talks to end Gaza war
summary: After a meeting in Cairo, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he welcomed Egypt's readiness to reach a deal 'for the release of the hostages' still held by militants in Gaza, then directed the head of Israel's Mossad spy agency to leave for key mediator Qatar on Sunday to 'advance a series of initiatives,' a statement from his office said.

title: LA prosecutor says will ask for resentencing of Menendez brothers over parents' killing
summary: Los Angeles County District Attorney George Gascón announced a decision on Thursday in the case of brothers Erik and Lyle Menendez, who have spent 34 years in prison for the shotgun murder of their parents.

title: Silence from the ICC judges hearing the Netanyahu case
summary: Issued by the prosecutor five months ago, the judges of the International Criminal Court are due to rule on the request for an arrest warrant against the Israeli prime minister.
